results.title: T is for Tumbleweed
results.creator_credit: Louis Clyde Stoumen, James A. Lebenthal and Camera Eye Pictures
results.brief_description: Portrays without commentary the racing, creeping, leaping travels of a tumbleweed and the encounters it has with people, animals and things. Photographed by Haskell Wexler.

results.title: Sweet are the fruits
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the growing and harvesting of pears, apricots and peaches in the Ardmona District of Northern Victoria. Shows the huge cannery in operation at Mooroopna - grading, peeling, coring, cutting, filling cans, adding syrup and sterilizing, labelling, packaging and finally despatching cartons. Gives a picture of a worker’s typical day and life in the caravan park. Features Joan Harris and Frederick Parslow.

results.title: Sunday in Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Paul Olson, Melbourne Repertory Film Unit and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: An experiment in the creative use of colour visuals, natural sound and dialogue commentary, this film shows the loneliness of the aimless wanderers in the city streets contrasted with those who have companionship on their Sunday. (Award: Special Award for an Experimental Film in the Australian Film Awards, Melbourne Film Festival, 1958) Rights held by Gil Brealey.

results.title: Summer school in Singapore
results.brief_description: As part of the Colombo Plan thirty-five students from Cambodia and Laos were invited by the United Kingdom Government to attend a summer-school in Singapore for a six-week course in the English language. The school was held in the University of Malaya and the students came from varied walks of life - government officials, teachers and high-school students. Emphasis was laid on conversational English, its rhythm, pronunciation and vocabulary.

results.title: Summer scene
results.brief_description: Shows tourist attractions of Western Australia’s South West region in spring and summer. Includes wildflowers, spectacular Karri forests near Pemberton and the Pemberton swimming pool, trout fishing, and Yallingup’s caves and rocky coastal beaches.

results.title: Struggle
results.creator_credit: Dale Butler, Peter Baroutis, Keith Morris and Eureka Films
results.brief_description: In an effort to salvage some land for recreational and park use in 1971, the residents of North Carlton, an inner suburb of Melbourne, came into opposition with the building contractor representing Kimberley-Clark Australia Pty Ltd. The company had proposed plans for building a warehouse for Kleenex products on the site. Unions joined forces with the residents against the building contractor, and the film shows some of those involved voicing their opinions and how events developed during the conflict. The confrontation leads to speeches, shouting, strong language, demonstrations and some violence and the increasing involvement of progressive Trade Unions in matters other than the bread-and-butter struggle. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Story of Menstruation
results.brief_description: This film was made as an outgrowth of Disney’s contract work with the armed forces during World War II. “The Story of menstruation” was probably the first American educational film with a woman narrator. The first half of the film discusses the natural process of menstruation through colourful yet simple diagrams, whilst the second half gives instruction on coping with behavioural changes and reinforcing gender roles, with a marriage scene followed by a picture of a young woman with her baby, suggesting “the natural course of life”. When this film was screened in schools, girls received a copy of a booklet, “Very Personally Yours”, which pushed Kotex products.

results.title: Emotions of everyday living: the steps of age
results.creator_credit: Ben Maddow, Helen Levitt and Film Documents
results.brief_description: A discussion of the problems confronting old age. The effect of inactivity on the lives of a crane-driver and his wife after his retirement are shown.

results.title: Soils of Australia
results.creator_credit: D.G. Corke, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Explains the classification and mapping of Australian soils, and discusses structure, nutrient status and current use of twelve soil groups in relation to their climatic zones.

results.title: Smokes and Lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Penny Chapman, 1:1 Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: First film in a longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, aged thirteen and fourteen. They talk about their attitudes to sex and boys, pregnancy, abortion, marriage, school, parenthood and their careers. Their hopes and ambitions pose special questions for adults and young people alike. Edited by David Pulbrook; sound by Rod Pascoe and photographed by Tom Cowan.
